questions.text: Choose the correct option in view of Holstein Lewis fracture:
questions.solution:
A special type of humerus fracture, where there is a spiral fracture at the junction of the middle and distal third, is commonly known to be associated with a radial nerve palsy. This is called Holstein Lewis fracture. The radial nerve injury results in paralysis of the wrist, finger and thumb extensors (wrist drop), brachioradialis and the supinator. There is a sensory change in a small area on the radial side of the back of the hand. The injury to the nerve is generally a neuropraxia only. It may be sustained at the time of fracture, during manipulation of the fracture or while the fracture is healing (nerve entrapment in the callus).

Topic: Nerve injuries and neuropathies >>> nerve injuries around humerus fractures

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 94

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, swelling, throbbing pain and inability to move the left middle finger. WBC counts, ESR and CRP were raised. X-ray was normal but USG showed findings suggestive of flexor tendon tenosynovitis. Salient features of Kanavel's signs are all except?
questions.solution:
Kanavel's signs which is typically seen in supparative tenosynovitis of fingers inludes following features

  • The finger is swollen (fusiformly) throughout its length
  • Acutely tender over the flexor tendon sheath
  • Finger is held in semi-flexed position, and
  • Active or passive extensionat the inter-phalangeal joint is very painful.

This is Kanavel's signs. This condition needs emergency management in the form of IV antibiotics and if needed then debridement and washout along the tendon sheath.

Redness can be seen in all infections and hence is not specific for tenosynovitis.

Topic: Flexor tendon tenosynovitis

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 209.

choices.text: Can be corrected by Pauwel's osteotomy
Is a complication seen in mal-union of Supracondylar humerus fracture
Usually does not cause any major functional disability

questions.text: False statement about the given image is?
questions.solution:
• Malunion: It is the commonest complication of a supracondylar fracture and results in a cubitus varus The cubitus varus deformity is often termed the Gun stock deformity. This is because the fracture unites with the distal fragment tilted medially and in internal rotation. Malunion may occur either because of failure to achieve good reduction, or displacement of the fracture within the plaster.
  • Treatment: Cubitus varus deformity is a cosmetic problem, usually withoutmuch functional Mild deformity may not require treatment, but a badly deformed elbow should be corrected. Treatment is a supracondylar corrective osteotomy (French/ Dome/Step cut osteotomy).
  • Pauwel's osteotomyis used for treating non-union of neck of femur fracture.

Topic: Cubitus varus

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 102.

choices.text: X-ray pelvis with both hips AP view
X-ray Left femur AP and Lateral view

questions.text: A 68yr old female patient is brought to outpatient department on a stretcher with complains of left hip pain and inability to walk after sustaining a fall in bathroom last night. On examination left lower limb is in external rotation and there is tenderness in left groin. What shall be your primary investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
According to the history and examination findings, it seems that an elderly (>60yrs) lady sustained trivial (mild/ low energy) trauma at home after which she is not able to walk with tenderness in groin and external rotation deformity, our differential diagnosis of the condition can be:

  1. Fracture neck of femur
  2. Fracture inter-trochanteric femur (In IT fracture the tenderness is over Greater trochanter along lateral aspect of upper thigh)

It is useful to ask for X-ray of pelvis with both hips, rather than that of the affected hip alone. This helps in comparing the two sides. The following features should be noted.

  • Break in the medial cortex of the neck.
  • External rotation of the femur is evident; the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent*.
  • Overriding of greater trochanter, so that it lies at the level of the head of the femur.
  • Break in the trabecular stream.
  • Break in Shenton’s line

CT scan is of no added importance in this case as x-ray is enough for diagnosis and for further plan of management.

Topic: Fractures around hip joint

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 134.

questions.text: Aviator's fracture is?
questions.solution:
Aviator's fracture: Fracture of neck of the talus.

In 1919, Anderson reported on a series of 18 fracture-dislocations of the talus in pilots of the Royal Flying Corps. It was the first descriptions on the mechanism of injury: dorsiflexion at the ankle with axial force, as a result of the rudder bar hitting the foot on impact in a crash landing. He called this injury “aviator's astragalus.”

Topic: Talus fractures

Reference: Rockwood and Green’s Fractures in Adult’s 9th edition, page number. 4614.

questions.text: A 24 yr old footballer presented with knee pain and swelling after sustaining a fall on football field while trying to kick the ball. His x-ray is normal but MRI shows complete ACL tear with haemarthrosis. All of the following clinical tests will be positive in that patient except?
questions.solution:
Clinical tests to check for patency of ACL are:

Anterior drawer test

Lachmann's test

Pivot shift test

McMurray's test is for examination of meniscal injuries.

Topic: Knee ligament injuries (acl)

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 356, 368.

questions.text: A 58 year female presents with history of fall on outstretched hand last night while going to washroom and pain in right shoulder region. X-ray shows comminuted surgical neck humerus fracture. Which classification system can be used for better plan of management?
questions.solution:
• It is important to properly evaluate these fractures by AP and axial X-rays.
  • Neerhas classified these fractures into 4 types depending upon the construction of the fracture. He identified 4 parts in the upper end of the humerus – shaft, head, greater tuberosity and lesser tuberosity.
  • Depending upon in how many parts the bone has fractured, he divided them into one to four-part fracture. For example, a fracture where the head, the greater tuberosity, the lesser tuberosity and the shaft, all have separated, it will be called a four-part fracture. This classification helps in deciding the treatment and prognosis.
  • Gartland fractureclassification is for supracondylar fracture humerus in children
  • Frykmann's fracture classification is for distal end radius fracturein adults
  • Schatzkerclassification is for proximal tibia fracture in adults.

Topic: Proximal humerus fractures (classifications)

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 92

choices.text: Stripping of the labrum from the postero-inferior surface of the glenoid and depression on the humeral head in its postero-medial quadrant.
Stripping of the labrum from the antero-inferior surface of the humeral head and depression on the glenoid in its postero-lateral quadrant.
Stripping of the labrum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant.
Stripping of the labrum from the postero-superior surface of the glenoid and depression on the humeral head in its antero-medial quadrant.

questions.text: True about Bankart and Hill sachs lesion as seen in these images in a case of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is?
questions.solution:
Bankart's lesion: Dislocation causes stripping of the glenoidal labrum along with the periosteum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck. The head thus comes to lie in front of the scapular neck, in the pouch thereby created. In severe injuries, it may be avulsion of a piece of bone from antero-inferior glenoid rim, called bony Bankart lesion.

CT image with 3D reconstruction of the glenoid shows “bony Bankart” lesion on the anterior inferior glenoid.

Hill-Sachs lesion: This is a depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant, caused by impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid on the head as it dislocates.

Axial T1-weighted MRI image shows “Hill–Sachs” lesion on the posterior lateral humeral head

MNEMONIC -

T- Traumatic anterior dislocation

U- Unilateral

B- Bankart's lesion (ant-inf labrum)

H- Hill-sach's lesion (post-lateral head)

S- Surgery is mandatory

Topic: Recurrent shoulder dislocation

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 90.

choices.text: Fracture of lower end of ulna with distal radio-ulnar joint dislocation
Fracture of upper end of ulna with proximal radio-ulnar joint dislocation
Fracture of lower end of radius with distal radio-ulnar joint dislocation
Fracture of upper end of radius with proximal radio-ulnar joint dislocation

questions.text: Monteggia fracture dislocation is best described by?
questions.solution:
Monteggia fracture dislocation - This is a fracture of the upper-third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. It may also result from a direct blow on the back of the upper forearm.

Galleazi fracture dislocation - This injury is the counterpart of the Monteggia fracture-dislocation. Here, there is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. It commonly results from a fall on an out stretched hand.

Topic: monteggia fracture dislocation

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 110.

questions.text: Identify the fracture marked in the x-ray given below?
questions.solution:
• Jone's fractureis a fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal, caused by the pull exerted by the tendon of the peroneus brevis muscle inserted on it. Clinically, there is pain, swelling and tenderness at the outer border of the foot, most marked at the base of the 5th metatarsal. Treatment is by a below-knee walking plaster cast for 3 weeks.
  • March fracture- It is a ‘fatigue’ fracture of third metatarsal, resulting from long continued or often repeated stress, particularly from prolonged walking or running in those not accustomed to it. Thus, it may occur in army recruits freshly committed to marching – hence the term ‘March fracture’. The fracture heals spontaneously, so treatment is purely symptomatic.
  • Maissoneuve's fracture: It is a type of ankle fracture in which fracture of the neck of the fibula occurs.
  • Pott’sfracture: Bimalleolar ankle fracture.

Topic: Jones fracture (fractures around foot)

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 3, 166

choices.text: Capitellum fracture, Supracondylar humerus fracture and Radial head fracture.
Coronoid process fracture, Radial head fracture and Elbow dislocation.
Elbow dislocation, Capitellum fracture and Radial head fracture.
Elbow dislocation, Coronoid process fracture and Radial neck fracture.

questions.text: Which combination of injuries forms the terrible triad of elbow?
questions.solution:
Terrible triad injuries consist of a fracture of the radial head and coronoid and an elbow dislocation. These injuries may be challenging to treat and suboptimal clinical outcomes have been commonly described in the past. Advances in our knowledge of elbow biomechanics and improvements in implants have resulted in improved patient outcomes.

Topic: fractures around elbow (terrible triad)

Reference: Rockwood and Green’s Fractures in Adult’s 9th edition, page number :2352

questions.text: Chance fracture occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
• Chance fracture: Also called seat belt fracture, the fracture line runs horizontally through the body of the vertebra, through and through, to the posterior
  • The physical exam finding of ecchymosis to the abdominal wall in the same region of where one wears a seat belt is called a “seat belt” sign.
  • This can be associated with an almost 5% increased risk of small bowel perforation.
  • The same force transmitted posteriorly along this anterior–posterior plane of distribution can result in Chance fractures, flexion-distraction injuries of the thoracolumbar spine, which are associated with hollow viscus injury.

Topic: Spine fractures (chance fracture)

Reference: Rockwood and Green’s Fractures in Adult’s 9th edition, page number. 733

questions.text: Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal is known as?
questions.solution:
Boxers' fracture: It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers.

Chauffeur fracture: An intra-articular, oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius.

Cotton's fracture: Trimalleolar ankle fracture.

Dancer's fracture - Oblique/ spiral fracture of the 5th metatarsal shaft extending in distal lateral to proximal medial direction.

Topic: Boxer's fracture

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 3

Reference: Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adult's 9th edition, page number. 4833

questions.text: Unhappy triad of O'Donoghue includes all except?
questions.solution:
Often the injury to medial collateral ligament, medial meniscus and anterior cruciate ligament occur together. This is called O'Donoghue triad. It is called an unhappy triad because it is a very complex knee injury and the patients remains unhappy if timely and accurate treatment is not done.

Though this combination is very rare to occur in daily practise. Lateral meniscus is more commonly injured along with ACL and MCL and hence this new triad is often named as revisited O'Donoghue triad.

Topic:Knee ligament injuries (unhappy triad)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 149

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady sustained trivial fall on outstretched hand at home and injured her left wrist. On examination there is a dinner fork deformity. X-ray left wrist AP and lateral views shows classical Colle's fracture. All of the following displacements can be seen on the x-ray except? Topic: Colles fracture
questions.solution:
In Colles' fracture, the fracture line runs transversely at the cortico-cancellous junction. In the majority of cases, one or more of the displacements described below occur; although in a few cases it may be a crack fracture without displacement. The following are the displacements seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Impaction of fragments
  • Dorsal displacement (shift)
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Lateral (radial) displacement (shift)
  • Lateral (radial) tilt
  • Supination

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 112

questions.text: A 36-year-old female homemaker presents to you with complains of pain, tingling and numbness in thumb, index and middle finger which becomes worse at night. She is a known patient of hypothyroidism with no recent history of injury to concerned area. You are suspecting carpal tunnel syndrome. Which test will not be helpful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome refers to the compressive neuropathy of median nerve in the carpal tunnel of wrist under the transverse carpal ligament. Patients usually presents with neuropathic pain in median nerve distribution of hand. Frequent association with hypothyroidism has been noted.

A carpal compression test (Durkan test), in which direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomizer bulb attached to a manometer, was found to be more specifc (90%) and more sensitive (87%) than either the Tinel or Phalen test.

Nerve conduction studies show delayed or absent conduction of impulses in the median nerve across the wrist in carpal tunnel syndrome.

Froment test or book test is for adductor pollicis weakness in ulnar nerve injury.

Topic: Carpal tunnel syndrome

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 3858

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 68, 304

choices.text: Sciatic nerve due to anterior dislocation of hip
Femoral nerve due to anterior dislocation of hip
Superior gluteal nerve due to posterior dislocation of hip
Sciatic nerve due to posterior dislocation of hip

questions.text: After a RTA, patient presents with flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformity of the hip and severe pain. What nerve is likely to get injured and why?
questions.solution:
The sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum. Therefore, it may be damaged in a posterior dislocation of the hip; more so if the dislocation is associated with a large bony fragment from the posterior lip of the acetabulum.

Topic: Complications of hip dislocation

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 56.

questions.text: A young male who sustained humerus shaft fracture was operated for ORIF with plating for the fracture. After surgery he developed neuropraxia injury of the radial nerve and the surgeon advised him to wear a dynamic wrist drop splint. Which muscle will not be affected and function normally in this patient?
questions.solution:
Radial nerve is commonly injured in the case of humerus shaft fracture either due to the fracture end or during ORIF surgery resulting in wrist drop. Usually it is a neuropraxia injury to the nerve which recovers well with supportive therapy using a dynamic wrist drop splint.

Wrist drop: The wrist remains in palmar flexion due to weakness of the dorsiflexors. It is seen in radial nerve palsy.

Muscles supplied by radial nerve are as follows:

After piercing the supinator radial nerve emerges in the posterior compartment of the forearm to become the posterior interosseous nerve, which divides immediately into branches supplying all the extensor muscles of the forearm which includes ECRL, ERCB, ECU, EDC, APL, EPB, EPL, EDM and EIP.

FCU is supplied by Ulnar nerve.

Topic: Radial nerve injury ( humerus shaft fracture)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number. 65

questions.text: Commonest type of dislocation?
questions.solution:
Different joints and their dislocations:

Topic: Joint dislocations.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number. 54

questions.text: Spina ventosa - choose correct option?
questions.solution:
Spina ventosa: This is a name given to tuberculosis of the phalanges of hand. The affected phalanx swells up like a balloon. An X-ray typically shows a lytic lesion distending the phalanx, and a lot of new bone formation.

TB spine is also called Pott's disease

TB shoulder is also called dry sicca

Topic: TB small bones (phalynx)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 203

questions.text: A 55 yr old gentleman who sustained fall on outstretched hand while going down the stairs was diagnosed to have distal radius fracture on x-ray. The fracture is quite displaced and unstable and hence needs surgical fixation. All these implants can be used for the same except?
questions.solution:
• Nails are implants that are used for intra-medullary fixation of fractures of the shaft (diaphysis) of long bones like femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, radius and ulna. K-nail (Kuntschner's nail) was specifically used for femur shaft fractures in the past. It is not commonly used these days due to availability of better nails for the same.
  • Distal radius fractures are fractures typically seen in the metaphyseal region or even distal to that towards the wrist joint (intra-articular fractures). These fractures are sometimes transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires which are incorporated in the plaster In some centres, an external fixator is used to keep the fracture 'distracted', so that the stretched ligaments and periosteum keep the comminuted fragments in place (ligamentotaxis). A more recent addition to the surgical treatment is to fix these fractures with LCP (Locking compression plate).

Topic: Distal radius fractures

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number:113

choices.text: Seen in common peroneal nerve palsy
Tibialis anterior muscle transfer is done for treatment

questions.text: False about foot drop is?
questions.solution:
Foot drop: The foot remains in plantar flexion due to weakness of the dorsiflexors.

It occurs in common peroneal nerve palsy. The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and the evertors of the foot. Paralysis of these muscles results in foot drop.

The patient walks with a 'high-step gait', i.e. while walking he has to lift the foot high in order to clear the ground. The plantar flexors of the foot are normal.

For long standing non-recovering foot drop: Transfer of tibialis posterior on the dorsum of the foot is done. Tibialis anterior is supplied by DPN (branch of CPN) and will loose power in foot drop.

Topic: Common peroneal nerve injures.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 69, 179

questions.text: Avascular necrosis is not a common complication of which fracture?
questions.solution:
Topic:complications of fractures (AVN)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 50

choices.text: Dislocation at proximal radio ulnar joint with upper ulna fracture
Dislocation of distal radio- ulnar joint with lower radius fracture
Displacement of one vertebrae over other

questions.text: Luxatio erecta is?
questions.solution:
Luxatio erecta: inferior dislocation of shoulder

Spondylolisthesis: movement of one vertebra over another (usually L4 over L5)

Galleazzi: fracture of distal 1/3 of the radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint

Monteggia: fracture of proximal 1/3 of the ulna with dislocation of head of the radius

Topic: Inferior shoulder dislocation

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number. 367

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to emergency room with complains of right hip pain following history of fall from standing height. An x-ray of pelvis with both hips was taken which was as follows. Which implant cannot be used to treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows neck of femur fracture on right side.

Internal fixation: Any of the following implants may be used for internal fixation of neck femur fracture:

  • Multiple cancellous screws - most commonly used.
  • Dynamic hip screw (DHS) - used sometimes.
  • Multiple Knowle's pins/Moore's pins used in children.

Hemiarthroplasty - This is a procedure used for elderly patients. In this, the head of the femur is excised and replaced by a prosthesis. There are two types of prosthesis commonly in use: unipolar and bipolar.

Proximal femoral nail is used for inter-trochanteric and sub-trochanteric femur fracture.

Topic: IT femur fracture

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page number:136, 139
